p: Nevertheless, one facet of adaptation actions to climate change is the diversification ( Schroth and Ruf, 2014). It may be achieved with moderate to high level of shade in coffee production, as suggested by Barradas and Fanjul (1986), Soto-Pinto et al. (2000). Although high levels of shade in coffee cultivation is not possible without yield reduction ( Rahn et al., 2014; Morais et al., 2006), financial and ecological possibilities may ariseby joining REDD program (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degration). in developing countries, with carbon credits ( Rahn et al., 2014), sustainable management, significant reductions in N-fertilizer inputs ( Rosenstock et al., 2014), and timber sales ( Sousa et al., 2016). Additionally, Rahn et al. (2014) highlights that sustainable coffee production reduces coffee carbon footprint, resulting in a financial gain in coffee commercialization.
